snippet: The debate before the Supreme Court today was over welfare policy -- whether states can have a lower level of benefits for newcomers than for longtime residents -- but the deeper issue was the meaning of citizenship.    California was asking the C...
lead_paragraph: The debate before the Supreme Court today was over welfare policy -- whether states can have a lower level of benefits for newcomers than for longtime residents -- but the deeper issue was the meaning of citizenship. California was asking the Court to permit it to do what Congress authorized in the 1996 welfare law: hold newcomers, for their first year of residency, to the welfare benefits they would have received in their home state, often hundreds of dollars a month lower.
abstract: Supreme Court hears debate over California's request to hold newcomers to welfare benefits they would have received in their home state; Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg says Court precedents on right to travel seem to indicate that new residents and longtime residents are entitled to equal treatment; Constitution does not mention right to travel, but decisions in 1960's derive it from guarantee of equal protection (M)
